title: Introducing England's answer to Tuscany (and Britain's happiest place)
text:
I’d had a bacon sandwich at a café called Puddleducks. Then I’d driven on. Now I stood above the village of Slaidburn, looking over moorland and fells undulating away indefinitely. Drystone walls imposed order, but not much.

Clouds swept across the sky, anxious to be elsewhere. I climbed on to a little rock, flung my arms wide and cried: “Ladies and gentlemen, I give you the Forest of Bowland. I give you the Ribble Valley. I give you… Lancashire!” Then I stepped down, to no applause. There was nobody else around.

Which is a key part of the appeal. This wonderful stretch of England is little populated, little visited and yet, according to Office for National Statistics figures released this week, the Ribble Valley – which includes the Forest of Bowland – is the happiest place in Britain. With a rating of 8.30 out of ten, it is very slightly happier than the second-placed Orkney islands on 8.29.
description: Explore Lancashire and the Forest of Bowland, one of England's areas of natural beauty, with our Telegraph Travel expert and see why this is our own Tuscany.
